description: From Middle French parité, from Late Latin paritas, from Latin pār (“equal”). Equivalent to pari- +‎ -ty.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Equality; comparability of strength or intensity.
examples: Altogether, Microsoft claims a 99% feature parity between 32-bit and 64-bit editions.

definitionGroups.group: Senses related to classification into two sets.

entries.meaning: (mathematics, countable) A set with the property of having all of its elements belonging to one of two disjoint subsets, especially a set of integers split in subsets of even and odd elements.
examples: Parity is always preserved in such operations.

entries.meaning: (mathematics, countable) The classification of an element of a set with parity into one of the two sets.
examples: The particles' parities can switch at random.

entries.meaning: (computing) The count of one bits in a value, reduced to even or odd or zero or one.
(physics, countable) Symmetry of interactions under spatial inversion.
(games, countable) In reversi, the last move within a given sector of the board.

description: From Latin paritas, from pariō (“give birth”).

entries.meaning: (medicine, countable) The number of delivered pregnancies reaching viable gestational age, usually between 20-28 weeks
(agriculture, countable) The number of times a sow has farrowed.
